para.paratext: In a criminal prosecution where the defendant enters a plea of not guilty, intent becomes a material issue.[1] In admitting evidence of other acts to show intent, the trial court must apply the three-prong test set out in Bradshaw v. State:[2] (1) the evidence must be relevant to an issue other than defendant's character; (2) the probative value must not be substantially outweighed by its undue prejudice; and (3) there must be sufficient proof so that the jury could find that defendant committed the act in question.

[A] defendant who enters a not guilty plea makes intent a material issue which imposes a substantial burden on the government to prove intent, which it may prove by qualifying Rule 404(b) evidence absent affirmative steps by the defendant to remove intent as an issue. Where the extrinsic offense is offered to prove intent, its relevance is determined by comparing the defendant's state of mind in perpetrating both the extrinsic and charged offenses. Thus, where the state of mind required for the charged and extrinsic offenses is the same, the first prong of the Rule 404(b) test is satisfied.[3]

Citing Bradshaw, in State v, Jones,[4] the Georgia Supreme Court held that “other acts evidence may be relevant under Rule 404(b), without regard to whether the charged crime is one requiring a specific or general intent, when it is offered for the permissible purpose of showing a criminal defendant's intent and knowledge …. Such evidence is relevant if the State articulates a clear hypothesis showing that the evidence offered has any tendency to prove or disprove the existence of any consequential fact independent of the use forbidden by Rule 404(b).”[5]

In Silvey v. State,[6] the Court of Appeals determined that admissibility of a prior burglary where the defendant stole a ring and pawned it for cash involved the same mental state as burglarizing a house to obtain gold jewelry to sell for cash, and therefore the extrinsic act was admissible to show intent.

In Eubanks v. State,[7] the Court of Appeals upheld the trial court where it allowed the admission of prior molestation of a 12-year-old girl by digital penetration to come in as a similar transaction. The court found no abuse of discretion where the acts, the age of the girls, and the motive of seeking nonconsensual sex from a minor girl were similar, although the acts occurred 17 years apart.

Likewise, the Court of Appeals allowed testimony from the victim's father regarding text messages the defendant sent to one of the victims. The defendant claimed he failed to receive the requisite notice from the state regarding the testimony. The court held a general notice that similar transactions would be used was sufficient.[8]

The Court of Appeals has also held that, while current rules require that notice be given, the trial court is no longer mandated to have a hearing; however, reasonable notice of similar transactions must be given by the state. Moreover, it is the defendant's responsibility to raise the objection of reasonableness to preserve it for appeal.[9]

In Humphrey v. Williams,[10] the Supreme Court examined similar transaction evidence offered in a child molestation case in context of a habeas corpus petition. The Court granted the petition and set aside the conviction, holding that the similar transaction evidence offered by the state would have been excluded from trial if documentary evidence of the previous case would have been presented to the trial court, or if not, then the documentary evidence should have been used to impeach the testimony of the witness who testified that the defendant had molested her, where court records supported the fact that the witness was a manipulator, and that the investigators in her case did not believe the abuse had taken place.

In Pope v. Probst,[11] the Georgia Court of Appeals held admissible, as a showing of intent in a fraud case, a similar transaction in which the defendant, a county housing inspector, took advantage of an elderly widow in a real estate transaction much like the present case in which he threatened to condemn an elderly homeowner's house if she did not sell it to him at a price below fair market value.

In Kent v. White,[12] the court found admissible evidence of an attorney's failure to pay an expert, subsequent to the events at issue, because the transactions were similar and both involved issues of bad faith and fraud and a pattern of concealment and deceit.

In Kothari v. Patel,[13] where a shareholder sued the corporation's principal for fraud, the court held admissible evidence of the principal's prior business relationships even though they related to the principal's dealings as a landlord with his tenant rather than as a principal with his shareholders. The court explained that, to be admissible, the other transactions must be close in time and part of a common scheme, because “frequently the state of mind accompanying the doing of an act is illustrated by other acts of a similar nature, done or proposed by the defendant in such a way as to indicate a general practice or course of conduct.”[14]

In Seaboard Coastline R. Co. v. Delahunt,[15] evidence that the plaintiff's supervisor had previously instructed him to disregard the railroad's safety rule regarding inspection of railroad cars before they were moved was admissible because it showed a course of conduct and explained why the plaintiff was not negligent in failing to inspect the railroad cars before they were moved.

The Court found that the record supported the trial court's conclusion that evidence of Jones' prior DUI conviction was offered for the permissible purpose of showing his intent because it had a tendency to make the existence of his general intent to drive under the influence more probable and would authorize a jury to logically infer that Jones was voluntarily driving while under the influence. Thus, there was no abuse of discretion in the trial court's decision to admit evidence of Jones' prior conviction for these limited purposes. The inquiry regarding the admissibility of Jones' prior conviction did not end there, however, because under the second Bradshaw prong, even evidence determined to be admissible under Rule 404(b) may be deemed inadmissible on the basis of prejudice, confusion or waste of time.
